dek: If your name is Baby, then seemingly every song is about you. But what if your name isn’t Baby?

nonPeopleText.value: Many people’s names can also be places (America, London etc.), brands (Chanel, Louis etc.), vehicles (Harley, Ford etc.), references to drugs (Molly, Mary Jane etc.) and other things that may not be related to an actual person.

buttonQuery: Do you want to include mention of these names anyway?

sections.title: What Is This?
sections.desc: A brief intro into this data-driven look at names in songs

sections.title: Popular Names
sections.desc: Find how your name stacks up

sections.title: Repeat Names
sections.desc: The songs that mention the same name over and over again

sections.title: Unique Names
sections.desc: The songs and artists that just name drop everyone

sections.desc: Watching the most popular names in songs change over 70 years

sections.title: First & Last Letters
sections.desc: The letters that start and end names in songs more often than in society

introPre: Let me set the scene for you. You’re having a lovely conversation with a perfect stranger when they say “What’s your name?” You respond by saying:

introPost.value: Let me set the scene for you. You’re having a lovely conversation with a perfect stranger when they ask you for your name. You tell them and without missing a beat, this kind stranger responds “Like the song?”

After discussing the songs that encourage your friends to endlessly croon your name (or the lack of songs thereof), you ask the stranger their name in return.  They reply “Baby”. Yes, like B-A-B-Y, Baby. And what can you say but “Like the song?” Afterall, isn’t every song about Baby?

This is a very rough re-enactment of a scene between two characters in the film Baby Driver. But the scene wasn’t purely fiction. In an analysis of over 15,000 songs from the Billboard Hot 100 list since 1950, “Baby” is, indeed, the most popular name to sing about by a longshot. We found 1,832 songs that sing about a person referred to as “Baby”. Sure, that could be a pet name or term of endearment, but Baby is a real name and it’s impossible for us to definitively separate those two things. Here are just a few examples:

introPlaylist.lyrics: “Baby, baby, where did our love go?”
introPlaylist.title: Where Did Our Love Go

introPlaylist.lyrics: “Baby, just remember I gave you my heart”
introPlaylist.title: Forever Your Girl

introPlaylist.lyrics: “Baby, I’m not always there when you call”
introPlaylist.title: Always on Time

introPlaylist.lyrics: “Baby, how you do that, make a grown man cry?”
introPlaylist.title: OMG

introPlaylist.lyrics: “Baby, I’m the one who put you up there.”
introPlaylist.title: Without Me

postPlaylist: But who else are artists singing about in the US’ largest songs? The sections of this story can be read in any order, so either scroll down or select a section on the left.
popularDek: Where does your name stack up?
popularProse: Alright, so we already know that “Baby” is the most popular name by far, but check out the other most popular names. Apart from Jesus, these names have a long history of popularity in the US. While many of these names hit their peak popularity in the 1950’s, many are still popular today, with Michael and John still ranking as the 8th and 26th and most common boy’s names in the US in 2016, respectively.
popularSearch: Interested in finding what songs include a mention of your name? Enter it into the search field below.
repeatDek: The songs that mention the same name over and over again
repeatProse: You know how some songs are just absolute ear-worms and they get stuck in your head for days? Well, some of the songs in this section make me wonder if names can be ear-worms too. If your name is Mickey, Scotty, Bennie, or (if you’re willing to ignore that this is actually a drug-reference) Molly, you’re probably already intimately familiar with these tunes. Check out the most name-repetitive hits or search for your favorites below.
repeatChartTitle: Songs with the Most Instances of the Same Name
repeatChartSub: Count of name mentions in a single song
